greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number A(n,k) of factorizations of m^n into at most n factors, where m is a product of exactly k distinct primes; square array A(n,k), n>=0, k>=0, read by antidiagonals.
comment: A(n,k) is also the number of k-partite partitions of (n)^k into at most n k-tuples.  A(2,2) = 5: [(2,2)], [(2,1),(0,1)], [(2,0),(0,2)], [(1,2),(1,0)], [(1,1),(1,1)].
example: A(2,2) = 5: (2*3)^2 = 36 has 5 factorizations into at most 2 factors: 36, 2*18, 3*12, 4*9, 6*6.
mathematica: b[n_, k_, i_] := b[n, k, i] = If[n>k, 0, 1] + If[PrimeQ[n] || i<2, 0, Sum[ If[d > k, 0, b[n/d, d, i-1]], {d, Divisors[n][[2 ;; -2]]}]]; A[0, _] = 1; A[1, _] = 1; A[_, 0] = 1; A[n_, k_] := With[{t = Times @@ Prime[ Range[k] ]}, b[t^n, t^n, n]]; Table[diag = Table[A[n-k, k], {k, n, 0, -1}]; Print[ diag]; diag, {n, 0, 10}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 08 2016, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 27 2015
